sls: of a product that is being sold

dt.t: This model {it}comes{/it} in several sizes. [=this model can be bought in several sizes]
a product that {it}comes{/it} in a variety of colors and shapes
when the product first {phrase}came on the market{/phrase} [=when the product was first being sold]

dt: {bc}to have something as a feature, quality, ability, etc.

dt.t: The car {it}comes{/it} (equipped/complete) with air-conditioning.
May I {it}fill{/it} your glass for you?
{it}fill{/it} (up) a glass with water
He told the gas station attendant to {it}fill{/it} it/her up. [=to fill the tank of his car with gasoline]
Clothes {it}filled{/it} the closet.
She {it}filled{/it} her house with antiques.
His massive body {it}filled{/it} the doorway.
He has enough books to {it}fill{/it} a library.
Two hundred people {it}filled{/it} the room.
{it}fill{/it} a sheet of paper with writing
Tears {it}filled{/it} her eyes. [=she began to cry]
Joy {it}filled{/it} her heart. [=she became very joyful]
He {it}filled{/it} her head with lies [=he told her many lies] about his military service.
pastries {it}filled{/it} with meat = meat-{it}filled{/it} pastries
a vase {it}filled{/it} with flowers
stadiums {it}filled{/it} with cheering fans
The theater was {phrase}filled to capacity{/phrase}. [=completely full]

dt: If something {phrase}fills you{/phrase} or {phrase}fills your heart{/phrase} with an emotion, it makes you feel that emotion very strongly.

dt.t: The thought of leaving {it}fills me{/it} with sadness. [=makes me very sad]
I'm {it}filled{/it} with shame [=I'm very ashamed] when I think of how I treated her.
The news {it}filled their hearts{/it} with hope. [=made them very hopeful]

t: At the end of the movie, the narrator goes back and {it}fills in{/it} (all) {it}the blanks{/it}. [=the narrator provides missing information about the movie's plot]

dt.t: She {it}backed{/it} into a parking space.
She {it}backed{/it} out of the garage.
The dog kept growling but {it}backed{/it} off/away cautiously.
Could you {it}back{/it} [=(more commonly) {it}back up{/it}] your car a little to give me some room?
The reporter {phrase}backed her into a corner{/phrase} [=put her into a difficult position that was hard to get out of] with his probing questions.

dt: {bc}to gradually destroy, use, or take away something {bc}to wear something away

dt.t: The rocks were {it}eaten away{/it} by erosion.
Marketing costs {it}ate into{/it} their profits.
The acids were {it}eating away at{/it} the metal finish.
The failure of his business has {it}eaten away at{/it} his confidence.

utxt.t: The novel's ending is not very {it}believable{/it}.
She's a firm/great/strong {it}believer{/it} in adult education. [=she firmly/strongly believes in the value of adult education; she thinks adult education is very useful and important]
I was doubtful that he could run his own company, but he's {phrase}made a believer out of me{/phrase}. = He's {phrase}made me a believer{/phrase}. [=he's convinced me that he can run his own company]
